description: Following a Sunday night of mostly peaceful protests punctuated by brief pockets confrontation with law enforcement, Memphis Mayor Jim Strickland and Memphis Police Director Michael Rallings announced a city-wide curfew, effective from 10 p.m. on Monday until 6 a.m. Tuesday. The protests have been spurred by the recent killings of Ahmaud Arbery, Breonna...
text:
Following a Sunday night of mostly peaceful protests punctuated by brief
pockets confrontation with law enforcement, Memphis Mayor Jim Strickland and
Memphis Police Director Michael Rallings announced a city-wide curfew,
effective from 10 p.m. on Monday until 6 a.m. Tuesday.

The curfew, Strickland and Rallings said, followed the largest night of
arrests since protests began in earnest on Wednesday. The protests have been
spurred by the recent killings of Ahmaud Arbery, Breonna Taylor and George
Floyd.

Floyd's death, in particular, ignited protests nationwide after a civilian
filmed former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin kneeling on Floyd's
neck for several minutes. Floyd, who repeatedly said he couldn't breathe, was
pronounced dead after the confrontation on Memorial Day.

Rallings, along with top law enforcement officials across the country, has
denounced the actions of Chauvin and the four officers who stood and watched,
but failed to act.

In total, 31 people were arrested as events unfolded over several hours in
Downtown and South Memphis. One of whom is a former Grizzlies player and
Memphis high school standout.

Nearly all of the individuals arrested are facing one or more misdemeanor
charges. The most common charges are obstruction of a highway or passageway,
and resisting arrest.

Two of the individuals charged are minors. The names of minors are not
released in public documents.

More than 40 individuals have been arrested since protests started last week.

The following are facing charges following Sunday night's protest, which
continued well into early Monday.

* Mercy Burr, 29, disorderly conduct

* Ross Rives, 30, disorderly conduct, obstruction of highway or passageway

* Michael Bowen, 24, disorderly conduct, obstruction of highway or passageway

* Giovanni Johnson, 20, disorderly conduct, obstruction of highway or passageway

* Cameron Burton, 24, disorderly conduct, obstruction of highway or passageway

* Aubri Stuart, 19, disorderly conduct

* Terrico Stewart, 18, disorderly conduct, obstruction of highway or passageway, and evading arrest

* Cedric Reed, 18 disorderly conduct, obstruction of highway or passageway

* Anteon Wooten, 18, disorderly conduct

* Don Eddings, 20, disorderly conduct

* Jeremiah Newson, 19 disorderly conduct, obstruction of highway or passageway

* Kennedi Ingram, 20, disorderly conduct, resisting official detention

* Jasmine Jackson, 30, disorderly conduct, public intoxication

* Mary Altizer, 20, disorderly conduct, public intoxication

* Jordan Johnson, 18, disorderly conduct, obstruction of highway or passageway, and evading arrest

* Devion Lewis, 18, disorderly conduct, obstruction of highway or passageway, and evading Arrest

* Caleb Cropper, 19, disorderly conduct, obstruction of highway or passageway

* Denorius Butler, 25, disorderly conduct, obstruction of highway or passageway

* Adam Guerrero, 40, disorderly conduct

* Marissa Walker, 19, disorderly conduct

* Jasmine Phelps, 23, obstructing highway or passageway, resisting official detention

* Courtney Campbell, 31 disorderly conduct

* Lester Hudson, 35, disorderly conduct, resisting official detention, unlawful carrying or possession of a weapon. Hudson is the former Grizzlies player.

* Matthew Scales, 31, disorderly conduct, obstructing Highway/Passageway, public intoxication

* Rodney White, 38, disorderly conduct

* Deangeleo Seals, 23, disregarding traffic signal, reckless driving

* Kavario Sayles, 18, reckless driving

* Curderrius Hawkins, 24, unlawful carrying or possession of a weapon

* Celia Kaptan, 20 disorderly conduct

* 17-year-old, theft of property

* 17-year-old, aggravated assault, evading arrest, and reckless endangerment

title: Memphis police arrest 31 people after fifth night of protests
html:
Following a Sunday night of mostly peaceful protests punctuated by brief pockets confrontation with law enforcement, Memphis Mayor Jim Strickland and Memphis Police Director Michael Rallings announced a city-wide curfew, effective from 10 p.m. on Monday until 6 a.m. Tuesday.

The curfew, Strickland and Rallings said, followed the largest night of arrests since protests began in earnest on Wednesday. The protests have been spurred by the recent killings of Ahmaud Arbery, Breonna Taylor and George Floyd.

Floyd's death, in particular, ignited protests nationwide after a civilian filmed former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin kneeling on Floyd's neck for several minutes. Floyd, who repeatedly said he couldn't breathe, was pronounced dead after the confrontation on Memorial Day.

Rallings, along with top law enforcement officials across the country, has denounced the actions of Chauvin and the four officers who stood and watched, but failed to act.

In total, 31 people were arrested as events unfolded over several hours in Downtown and South Memphis. One of whom is a former Grizzlies player and Memphis high school standout.

Nearly all of the individuals arrested are facing one or more misdemeanor charges. The most common charges are obstruction of a highway or passageway, and resisting arrest.

Two of the individuals charged are minors. The names of minors are not released in public documents.

More than 40 individuals have been arrested since protests started last week.

The following are facing charges following Sunday night's protest, which continued well into early Monday.

* Mercy Burr, 29, disorderly conduct

* Ross Rives, 30, disorderly conduct, obstruction of highway or passageway
